DEADLAUS: CHAPTER 4
After Captain Stark was disposed of on Planet Forendor, Charles became the Captain.

They explored a few Nebulas, then came to planet Earatoo, there they explored and found an Alien Artifact, but then the 6-man expedition team was captured by the Mush! At least 2 of them escaped, however 1 died, and 3 others were taken.

The Daedalus crew flew back to the Nebula where they met some new allies, and then Stark escaped and killed Samuel, because Stark was insane.

They then flew to planet Jauvei, which was full of female male-hating aliens who, upon finding a male, would (CENSORED) him.

They bought some stuff there, and found some crew members who had deserted them back on Planet Forendor.

They then traveled to Planet Dakarr where they came across the remains of the Alien Fleet that had captured their crew members back on Earatoo, and are now exploring the remains of that fleet.

[8356287]

Cool, the skill use modifiers look good to me.

I love the idea of making it truly harder to achieve the higher level skills, but if you roll a 100 with -60, you'll never get 80. Same with -40. With a -20 you've got a 1% chance.

So instead of modifiers, how about just having different score goals?

Easy: 75 (Gives Basic Training)
Medium: 80 (Gives Advanced Training)
Hard: 85 (Gives Expert Training)
Insanity: 90 (Gives Unique Skill)

A character would have to try 4 times on average to achieve Basic, then 5 times for Advanced, then approx. 7 times for Expert, then 10 times for Unique. So a total of 26 sessions (on average) for absolute maximum training. Does that sound reasonable?

On july 23, 2014
[8356287]

EoN, Shadow raised a good point that allowing characters to have lots of skills would get messy, both for the story, and for you managing it. So, extending from what we talked about last night (with some tweaks to the terms and numbers), here's what I propose:

There are 5 skill levels:

  • Unskilled: -50%
  • Basic: -25%
  • Competent: -10%
  • Skilled: +10%
  • Expert: +25%

Each character has 4 skill slots. The number of slots filled (regardless of skill level) determines an additional modifier:

  • Unique: Only one skill, +25% to all rolls for Unique Skill
  • Normal: Two or three skills, no modifier
  • Generalist: Four skills, -10% to all rolls

Characters advance in skill level by completing a simulation of a certain difficulty, with a certain score (d100):

  • Easy: 75% to pass, gives Basic skill
  • Medium: 80% to pass, gives Competent skill
  • Hard: 85% to pass, gives Full Skill
  • Insane: 90% to pass, gives Expert Skill

Characters must start on Easy difficulty, and must pass each level before moving on to the next. Each attempt takes 1 hour, and only 2 attempts can be made per post. If a character is stuck in the Sim, they can't be doing anything else during that time.

How does that look?

HarrivchanSo now we can only have 3 skills ?

You can have 4 skills, but then you'd get a "Generalist" penalty of -10% to all rolls. There's no penalty for having 2-3 skills. You'd actually get a +25% bonus if you only have one skill. Anyway, the maximum is 4 skills.

If you don't want the Listener or Diplomat skills, feel free to drop them and take different skills. Ron is your character, so that's your right.

[8356287]

shadowlake Well, Charles made a big impression on her....


Misterme7 I should probably mention what those percentage modifiers mean in the skills system. When we roll for a skill action, it looks like this:

d100% d100

The first roll is the chance of success. The second roll is the actual attempt. If the second roll is less than or equal to the first roll, then the action succeeded. Any modifiers are applied to the chance of success.

If the modified chance is zero or less, that's critical failure - something bad will happen, like the character will hurt themselves. If it's 100 or more, then the action succeeds fantastically. In combat, that's 2x damage. (Although we don't really keep track of HP much.) For other skills, it's interpreted however you want.

The rules aren't as rigid as most RPGs, we make up a lot of stuff as we go. We're just having fun writing a story. The dice just make it more interesting.
